DataElement.preferredName: Baseline To EKG ST Segment Depression Duration Duration Second Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The length of time measured in seconds from the beginning of an EKG to the onset of ST segment depression.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Baseline To EKG ST Segment Depression Duration
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Baseline; an imaginary standard by which things are measured or compared._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._The normal ST segment of the EKG tracing begins at the isoelectric line, is typically isoelectric (flat), extending from the end of the S wave and curving gradually upward to the beginning of the T wave. Causes of ST segment depression include myocardial ischemia, digoxin effect, ventricular hypertrophy, acute posterior myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolus, left bundle branch block._The period of time during which something continues.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Baseline To EKG ST Segment Depression
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Baseline; an imaginary standard by which things are measured or compared.:Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.:The normal ST segment of the EKG tracing begins at the isoelectric line, is typically isoelectric (flat), extending from the end of the S wave and curving gradually upward to the beginning of the T wave. Causes of ST segment depression include myocardial ischemia, digoxin effect, ventricular hypertrophy, acute posterior myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolus, left bundle branch block.

Concepts.definition: A starting point to which things may be compared.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.

Concepts.longName: ST Segment Depression by ECG Finding
Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of ST segment depression below the baseline, often described as up sloping, down sloping or horizontal.

Property.preferredDefinition: The period of time during which something continues.

Concepts.definition: The period of time during which something continues.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The period of time during which something continues._A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour._Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The period of time during which something continues.:The second is the unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour. Abbreviation Sec. is acceptable in non-scientific usage only.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: The period of time during which something continues.

A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
